Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Economic Downturns, Global Pandemics and Parliamentary Elections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Under what conditions do voters withdraw or withhold their support from governments and how do economic and pandemic stressors affect popular support for governments and political leaders? This project advances understanding of how electoral rules, electoral integrity, perceptions of regime popularity and longevity, and the nature of electoral alternatives shape government support. Using surveys timed to Russia’s 2021 parliamentary election and including questions from the Comparative Study of Electoral Systems, this project extends the longest running election study in an autocratic setting and the only covering an extended period of retreat from democracy. The data from this project are an important resource for scholars of authoritarianism, comparative electoral behavior, and political parties, and its findings are also relevant to journalists, policymakers and the public. <br/><br/>Existing scholarship gives good reason to believe that declining popular support can undermine regimes around the world. However, the precise nature of these processes and the long-term developments that lead to regime change remain poorly understood. This study uses a nationally representative panel survey conducted before and after Russia’s 2021 State Duma election to advance knowledge on two of the most consequential forms of political behavior and politically salient metrics of a regime’s popular support: turnout and vote choice. The project’s theoretical contribution focuses on key differences in how voters process information about government performance and assess available political alternatives, with special attention to how polarization, preference falsification, and voters’ emotional states affect their interpretation of new information during crises.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Voting in an Authoritarian Regime Under Stress: The 2021 Russian Election Study

This project explores the dynamics of mass support for autocracy in times of crisis. We ask: Under what conditions do voters withdraw or withhold their support from autocratic regimes and how do regime stressors like an economic downturn, a global pandemic, war, and unresolved issues of succession affect support for an authoritarian regime? Using an experiment-bearing panel survey timed to Russia’s 2021 parliamentary election, our project advances understanding of how polarization, electoral integrity, perceptions of regime popularity and longevity, and the nature of electoral alternatives shape support for Vladimir Putin’s regime.   In the first wave of the study (August-September 2021), we collected a nationally representative sample of approximately 2,750 respondents in face-to-face interviews. This was the largest face-to-face pre-election survey ever conducted in Russia. In the second wave of the study (November-December 2021) we reinterviewed 1,772 of those respondents in the panel portion of the survey. We also added an additional 1,200 respondents in a nationally representative refresh sample. With probability weights, we are able to construct a nationally representative post-election sample of 2,972 respondents. This is one of the largest face-to-face post-election surveys ever conducted in Russia and, to our knowledge, the largest ever election panel survey.  These surveys will form part of the Russian Election Studies (RES) series, which has covered every national election cycle in Russia for the past nearly three decades. On the basis of the RES, our research team has produced a number of academic articles and editorials and engaged in public outreach via public lectures.

In addition, we empaneled respondents in the December 2021 wave of the survey which has enabled us to commission reinterviews with these same respondents after the start of the war in Ukraine. This panel survey will be a unique opportunity to gauge how and why the war has changed a range of political attitudes in Russia.  To our knowledge, this would be the only available panel survey allowing researchers to examine how attitudes in Russia have shifted after February 2022.

Our research sheds light on citizens’ interactions with parties and elections under autocracy, a central subject of scholarly inquiry. The RES has continued uninterrupted over every Russian national election cycle since 1995, with post- (and often pre-) election surveys, often with panel components spanning one or more elections. The continuation of the RES -- the longest running election study in an autocratic setting and the only covering an extended period of authoritarian consolidation and construction of a dominant party system -- contributes an important resource for scholars of authoritarianism, comparative electoral behavior, and political parties. The resulting data will be made available to the broader scholarly community along with previous RES surveys.

By elucidating current political developments in Russia and providing appropriate historical context, this project contributes to public knowledge on a country of vital national security interest. We expect its findings on citizens’ views of election integrity, the opposition, and regime support will be of particular interest to journalists and policymakers.
